title: How to turn protest into powerful change - Eric Liu

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the core strategies for peacefully turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power?

options.label: A
options.text: Expanding the frame of the possible, choosing a defining fight, and finding an early win.

options.label: B
options.text: Choosing a defining fight, finding an early win, and expanding the frame of the possible.

options.label: C
options.text: Finding an early win, expanding the frame of the possible, and choosing a defining fight.

options.label: D
options.text: Expanding the frame of the possible, finding an early win, and choosing a defining fight.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of choosing a defining fight in the context of protest and civic life?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a contrast with something else in order to force a bigger debate.

options.label: B
options.text: To set the terms of a debate on your own terms over an issue that captures the essence of the change you want.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a sharp emblematic contrast and expand the frame of the possible.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a positive feedback loop and a contagion of belief and motivation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of an early win in the context of protest and civic life?

options.label: A
options.text: An early win creates momentum and changes what people think is possible.

options.label: B
options.text: An early win is not as important as the ultimate goal.

options.label: C
options.text: An early win is only achieved through violence and conflict.

options.label: D
options.text: An early win is only achieved through individual effort and not through collective action.

multiple-choice.question: What is the spirit of protest, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The spirit of protest is powerful, but it is not enough on its own.

options.label: B
options.text: The spirit of protest is only for special individuals.

options.label: C
options.text: The spirit of protest is only for a select few.

options.label: D
options.text: The spirit of protest is only for those who are already powerful.

multiple-choice.question: What is required to be part of the grind of expanding the frame of the possible, choosing a defining fight, or securing an early win?

options.label: A
options.text: You have to be anyone special.

options.label: B
options.text: You have to be a participant and live like a citizen.

options.label: C
options.text: You have to be a leader and have a lot of power.

options.label: D
options.text: You have to be a follower and not take any action.

title: Self-assembly: The power of organizing the unorganized - Skylar Tibbits

multiple-choice.question: What is self assembly, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A process where parts are thrown away when they break

options.label: B
options.text: A system where unordered parts come together in an organized structure on their own

options.label: C
options.text: A process where objects are reproduced by humans

options.label: D
options.text: A phenomenon that only occurs in the chemical world

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self assembly in biology, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of snowflakes

options.label: B
options.text: The folding of proteins into 3-D structures

options.label: C
options.text: The replication of DNA

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is an advantage of using self assembly in technology, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes technologies more reliant on fossil fuels

options.label: B
options.text: It makes technologies less adaptive and more difficult to build

options.label: C
options.text: It makes technologies easier to build, more adaptive, and less reliant on fossil fuels

options.label: D
options.text: It makes technologies more expensive

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self assembly being used in technology, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Making molecular microchips for computers

options.label: B
options.text: Making 3-D structures with DNA

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential future application of self assembly, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Making materials that cannot repair themselves

options.label: B
options.text: Making buildings that cannot adapt to their environment

options.label: C
options.text: Making space structures that cannot self assemble

options.label: D
options.text: Making materials that can repair themselves, water pipes that can reconfigure on demand, and buildings that can adapt to their environment

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the benefit of cognitive diversity in a team?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a decrease in collective intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: It results in a homogenous group of people with the same ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a massive uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the outcome of a task.

multiple-choice.question: Why are people attracted to those who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are trying to challenge their own perspectives.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it makes them feel smarter and validates their world view.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are trying to learn from others.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are trying to avoid conflict.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with surrounding oneself with people who think in the same way?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a decrease in confidence.

options.label: B
options.text: It results in no uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a decrease in creativity.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the outcome of a task.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key feature of competitive advantage for the next 50 years?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive diversity.

options.label: B
options.text: Cognitive homogeneity.

options.label: C
options.text: Collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Innovation.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it wrong to believe that one's model is the best and therefore should be working with people who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is not a logical conclusion.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is spectacularly wrong.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is not a good business strategy.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not a good way to learn.
